Answer: 50% HereтАЩs what the speaker says: NINA: Wish we were students тАУ look! Children, Students and Senior Citizens get a 50% discount on everything. The answer is 50%, which is the discount on all tickets. SECTION 2 11. Answer: 1.30 HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ weтАЩre open every day of the week from 9.00 a.m to 8.00 p.m. except onMondays when we close at 1.30 p.m. So, although the Museum closes at 8.00 p.m. on six days of the week, on Mondays it closes at 1.30 p.m. The answer is 1.30 12. Answer: 25th December/25 December/Christmas Day HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ And, in fact the only day of the year when weтАЩre closed is on the 25th of December. So, the answer is 25th December/25 December/Christmas Day. 13. Answer: car park/parking lot HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ If you bring a school group to the museum, when you arrive we ask you to remain with your group in the car park. One or more of the tour guides will welcome you thereтАж meet = welcome Therefore, the answer is car park/parking lot. 14. Answer: 45 HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ if you bring a school group, you should plan on allowing a minimum of 90 minutes for the visit. This allows 15 minutes to get on and off the coach, 45minutes for the guided tour and 30 minutes for after-tour activities. So, out of the minimum recommended visit to the Museum, the guided tour takes 45 minutes. The answer is 45. 15. Answer: (some) tables. HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ There are two cafes in the museum, with seating for 80 people. If you want to eat there, youтАЩll need to reserve some seating, as they can get quite crowded at lunch time. Then outside the museum at the back there are tables, and students can bring their own lunch and eat it there in the open air. behind = at the back of Therefore, if students bring their own lunch, there are tables in the open air behind the museum where they can eat. The answer is (some) tables. 16-18: Answer: C. cameras, F. pens, G. worksheets HereтАЩs what the speaker says: When the students come into the museum foyer we ask them to check in their backpacks with their books, lunch boxes, etc, at the cloakroom before they enter the museum proper. IтАЩm afraid in the past we have had a few things gone missing after school visits so this is a strict rule. Also, some of the exhibits are fragile and we donтАЩt want them to be accidentally knocked. But we do provide school students with handouts with questions and quizzes on them. ThereтАЩs so much that students can learn in the museum and itтАЩs fun for them to have something to do. Of course theyтАЩll need to bring something to writewith forthese. We do allow students to take photographs. For students who are doing projects itтАЩs useful to make some kind of visual record of what they see that they can add to their reports. And finally, they should not bring anything to eat into the museum, or drinks of any kind. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answers (C, F, G): bags = backpacks worksheets = handouts Explanation: The students are not allowed to come in the museum with backpacks (or bags) and books which will be checked in when they enter. So D and E are wrong answers. In addition, it is said that тАЬthey should not bring anything to eat into the museum, or drinks of any kindтАЭ so food and water is out of the question too, hence A and B are wrong. The speaker says that the students will be provided handouts with questions and quizzes on them, which can be considered тАЬworksheetsтАЭ and of course can be carried into the museum. Thus, Gis correct. And the students need to bring something to write with, which are obviously тАЬpensтАЭ so F is correct too. Finally, taking photographs is allowed in the museum and it can only be done by bringing a camera. C is also correct. So, the correct answers are C, F, G. 19-20: Answer: B. watch films, E. play computer games HereтАЩs what the speaker says: There are also a few things the students can do after the tour. In the theatrette on the ground floor there are continuous screenings of short documentaries about dinosaurs which they can see at any time. We used to have an activity room with more interactive things like making models of dinosaurs and drawing and painting pictures, even hunting for dinosaur eggs, but unfortunately the room was damaged in a bad storm recently when water came in the roof, so thatтАЩs closed at the moment. But we do have an IT centrewhere students have access to CD ROMs with a range of dinosaur games. These games are a lot of fun, but they also teach the students about the lives of dinosaurs, how they found food, protected their habitat, survived threats, that kind of thing. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answers (B E): films = documentaries find = hunt Explanation: Students can watch documentaries, which are a type of film, so B is correct. It is said that the activity room where the students can make dinosaur models, draw pictures and hunt for eggs is currently closed, meaning that they CANNOT do these activities now. Hence, A, C and D are incorrect. Lastly, students have access to тАЬCD ROMs with a range of dinosaur gamesтАЭ which means they can play games on computers, hence E is correct. The answers are B, E. SECTION 3 21. Answer: A. should be re-ordered in some parts. HereтАЩs what the speaker says: TUTOR: And IтАЩve made a few notes on the proposal about things whichcould have been better sequenced. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (A): order = sequence Explanation: тАЬsequenceтАЭ means тАЬarrange in a particular orderтАЭ, so the proposal is not well-ordered in some parts and needs re-ordering. The correct answer is A. 22. Answer: C. shortened her sentences. HereтАЩs what the speaker says: TUTOR: Generally speaking, I feel youтАЩve often used complex structures and long sentences for the sake of it and as a consequence . . . although your paragraphing and inclusion of sub-headings help . . . itтАЩs quite hard to follow your train of thought at times. So cut them down a bit, can you? Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (C): insert = inclusion shorten = cut down Explanation: The question asks what Sandra could do to improve her proposal, something she hasnтАЩt done yet. According to the recording, we know that SandraтАЩs paragraphing and subheadings help, meaning that she has already done those two things, so A and B are not correct. Instead, the speaker suggests Sandra тАЬcut downтАЭ her long sentences, which means that they need to be тАЬshortenedтАЭ. The answer is C. 23. Answer: A. Separate points were not clearly identified. HereтАЩs what the speakers say: TUTOR: And donтАЩt forget simple formatting like numbering. SANDRA: DidnтАЩt I use page numbers? TUTOR: I didnтАЩt mean that. Look, youтАЩve remembered to include headers and footers, which is good, but listing ideas clearly is important. Number them oruse bullet points, which is even clearer. Then youтАЩll focus the reader on your main points. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (A): points = ideas Explanation: The tutor says he didnтАЩt mean тАЬthatтАЭ which refers to SandraтАЩs page numbering, so we understand that page numbering is not the problem thus C is incorrect. There is no mention of the headings (only a reference to тАШheaders and footersтАЩ), so B is irrelevant. However, the tutor recommends тАЬlisting ideas clearlyтАЭ (by numbering or using bullet points), indicating that Sandra didnтАЩt make her points clear and separate from one another. Thus, the correct answer is A. 24. Answer: B. movies she saw as a child. HereтАЩs what the speaker says: SANDRA: IтАЩve always wanted to go there. My father was a great fan of cowboy films and the Wild West so I was subjected to seeing all the epics, many of which were shot there. As a consequence, it feels very familiar to me and itтАЩs awesome both geographically and visually, so itтАЩs somewhere IтАЩvealways wanted to visit. The subsequent research I did and the online photographs made me even keener. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (B): movies = epics the internet = online Explanation: Sandra says that she has always wanted to visit the park тАЬas a consequenceтАЭ of the epic movies she watched. Subsequently, she did research (which can be considered similar to тАЬreading articlesтАЭ) and looked at online photos, which made her тАЬeven keenerтАЭ, meaning she was keen before, so these two factors came after the cowboy movies. It was the movies that made her interested in the first place. The correct answer is B. 25-27: B. field trip activities, C. geographical features, F. plant and animal life HereтАЩs what the speakers say: SANDRA: Well, I thought that from the perspective of a field trip, one thing I needed to focus on was the sandstone plateaux and cliffs themselves (тАж) TUTOR: Well, yes, IтАЩd agree with including those points . . . SANDRA: And then the fact that itтАЩs been home to native American Navajos and all the social history that goes with that. (тАж) TUTOR: Well, I agree itтАЩs interesting, but itтАЩs not immediately relevant to your proposal, Sandra, so at this stage, I suggest you focus on other considerations. I think an indication of what the students on the trip could actually do when they get there should be far more central, so that certainly needs to be included and to be expanded upon. And IтАЩd like to see somethingabout the local wildlife, and vegetation too, not that I imagine thereтАЩs much to see. Presumably the tourist invasion hasnтАЩt helped. SANDRA: Okay, IтАЩll do some work on those two areas as well. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answers (B, C, F): plant = vegetation animal life = wildlife Explanation: The tutor agrees with SandraтАЩs idea about focusing on тАЬsandstone plateaux and cliffsтАЭ, which are тАЬgeographical featuresтАЭ, so C is correct. The tutor also suggests mentioning what students could do on the trip (= activities) and something about local wildlife and vegetation (similar to тАЬplant and animal lifeтАЭ), hence B and F are correct as well. The recording does not include information about тАЬclimate changeтАЭ or тАЬmyths and legendsтАЭ so A and E are irrelevant. Finally, the tutor opposes SandraтАЩs initial intention of includingthe тАЬsocial historyтАЭ of the natives in her proposal, therefore G is clearly wrong. The correct answers are B, C and F. 28. Answer: 12,000. HereтАЩs what the speakers say: TUTOR: тАжbut what area does the tribal park cover? Do you know? SANDRA: 12,000 hectaresтАж.. The answer is clearly 12,000. 29. Answer: horses HereтАЩs what the speaker says: SANDRA: I think the best way to appreciate the area would be to hire horses instead and trek around on those. Biking is not allowed and itтАЩs impossible to drive around the area in vehicles. Her suggestion is that they use horses to travel around in the Park. The answer is horses. 30. Answer: caves HereтАЩs what the speakers say: TUTOR: Okay, lastly, what else is worth visiting there? SANDRA: There are several caves, but I havenтАЩt looked into any details. IтАЩll find out about them. Explanation: the tutor asks about other places worth visiting in the park. Sandra mentions only the caves, so this must be the correct answer. The answer is caves. SECTION 4 31. Answer: surface HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ Well, we learn a great deal about all the processes that have affected and that continue to affect the EarthтАЩs surface. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (surface): effects (noun) = affect (verb) Explanation: the speaker talks about the processes that have an effect on the surface of the Earth, so the answer is surface. 32. Answer: environment HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ But we learn far more than that, because studying geography also informs us about the different kinds of relationships that develop between a particularenvironment and the people that live there. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (environment): population = people that live there Explanation: when relationships develop between 2 things, this is called a тАШdynamicтАЩ relationship. In this case, the developing relationship is between a specific environment and the population in that environment. The answer is environment. 33. Answer: impact HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ We like to think of geography as having two main branches. ThereтАЩs the study of the nature of our planet тАУ its physical features, what it actually looks like тАУ and then thereтАЩs the study of the ways in which we choose to live and of the impact of those on the planet. Our current use of carbon fuels is a good example of that. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (impact): human lifestyles = the way we choose to live Explanation: the speaker now talks about the 2 branches of geography. Firstly, there is the study of physical features and, secondly, there is the study of our way of life/lifestyles and how these affect (= impact on) the planet. The answer is impact(s)/effect(s). 34. Answer: urban HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ But there are more specific study areas to consider too, and weтАЩll be looking at each of these in turn throughout this semesterтАжтАжтАжNext comes historical geography тАУ the understanding of how people and their environments and the ways they interact have changed over a period of time тАУ and urban geography, an aspect IтАЩm particularly interested in, which takes as its focus the location of cities, the services that those cities provide, and migration of people to and from such cities. And lastly, we have cartography. Explanation: the speaker describes each of the specific study areas. This description follows the order of the different types of geography given in the question. Thus, after historical geography, the speaker then refers to the missing study area тАУ urban geography. After describing this, the speaker then mentions the final study area тАУ cartography. Therefore, the answer is urban. 35. Answer: problems HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ So, to summarise before we continue, we now have our key answerтАж. studying this subject is important because without geographical knowledge, we would know very little about our surroundings and we wouldnтАЩt be able to identify all the problems that relate to them. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (problems): associate= relate to Explanation: the speaker refers to the тАШkey answerтАЩ to explain why geography is useful and necessary to study. If we do not understand our surroundings, then we cannot solve the problems that face us. The answer is problems. 36. Answer: images HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ What do geographers actually do? Well, we collect data to begin with ! тАж.We might, for example, conduct a census тАУ count a population in a given area perhaps. We also need images of the earthтАЩs surface which we can produce by means of computer-generation technology or with the help of satellite relays. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (images): information = data Explanation: referring to what geographers do, the speaker gives examples of the kind of data that they collect. The first example is conducting a census, and then тАУ using computers and satellites тАУ images of the earthтАЩs surface can be obtained. The answer is images. 37. Answer: patterns HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ After weтАЩve gathered our information, we must analyse it ! We need to look for patterns, most commonly those of causes and consequences. Here are some key words that help you to get the correct answer (patterns): effects = consequences Explanation: the speaker says that geographers then analyse the information, in particular looking for patterns, especially causes and effects/ consequences. The answer is patterns. 38. Answer: distortion HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ Maps can be folded and put in a pocket and can provide a great store of reference when theyтАЩre collected into an atlasтАж.. But there is a drawback. You canтАЩt exactly replicate something that is three-dimensional, like our planet, on a flat piece of paper, because paper has only two dimensions, and that means thereтАЩll always be a certain degree of distortion on a map. Explanation: the speaker talks about the advantages of maps, but also mentions one drawback. The problem is that maps are printed on paper. Paper has two dimensions, but the planet has three dimensions, so there will always be some distortion on a map тАУ it wonтАЩt be an exact representation. The answer is distortion. 39. Answer: traffic HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ We can also use aerial photographsтАж. pictures taken by cameras at high altitude above the earth. They are great for showing all kinds of geographical features that are not easy to see from the ground. You can easily illustrate areas of diseased trees or how much traffic is on the roads at a given time or information about deep sea beds, for example. Explanation: the speaker refers to aerial photographs. There are examples of some of the uses of these photos to show physical features: vegetation problems = areas of diseased trees; traffic density = how much traffic is on the roads; and ocean floor = deep sea beds. So, the answer is traffic. 40. Answer: weather HereтАЩs what the speaker says: тАУ Then there are Landsats. These are satellites that circle the earth and transmit visual information to computers at receiving stations. They circle the earth several times a day and can provide a mass of information тАУ youтАЩll all be familiar with the information they give us about the weather, for example. Explanation: finally, the speaker talks about Landsats and what they do. They have many uses, including monitoring (= giving information about) the weather conditions. The answer is weather.

posts.title: Cambridge Academic Reading 16 Test 4
posts.content_clean: Reading Passage 1 Questions 1тАУ13 1 The correct answer is тАШpostsтАЩ: In the first paragraph, the text describes the тАШqanat methodтАЩ of construction, тАШwhich consisted of placing posts over a hill in a straight line, to ensure that the tunnel kept to its routeтАЩ. This means that the posts were placed to direct the tunnelling. тАШShaftsтАЩ is incorrect: The text says that the shafts were dug down into the ground after the posts were put in position. 2 The correct answer is тАШcanalтАЩ: In the first paragraph, the text says, тАШOnce the tunnel was completed, it allowed water to flow from the top of a hillside down towards a canal, which supplied water for human use.тАЩ The words тАШflowтАЩ and run have the same meaning in this context, and the phrase тАШfor human useтАЩ means that the canal supplied water for local people. 3 The correct answer is тАШventilationтАЩ: In the first paragraph, the text says, тАШThe excavated soil was taken up to the surface using the shafts, which also provided ventilation during the work.тАЩ This sentence explains two uses of the shafts: for removing earth and also for ventilation. This means that workers underground had access to fresh air through the shafts. 4 The correct answer is тАШlidтАЩ: In the second paragraph, the text describes Roman qanat tunnels, saying, тАШThe shafts were equipped with handholds and footholds to help those climbing in and out of them and were covered with a wooden or stone lid.тАЩ 5 The correct answer is тАШweightтАЩ: In the second paragraph, the text says, тАШRomans hung a plumb line from a rod placed across the top of each shaft and made sure that the weight at the end of it hung in the center of the shaft.тАЩ The diagram shows a weight hanging in the centre of the shaft at the end of the plumb line. тАШRodтАЩ is incorrect: The text says that the rod was at the top of the shaft, and the diagram shows this. 6 The correct answer is тАШclimbingтАЩ: In the second paragraph, the text describes Roman qanat tunnels, saying, тАШThe shafts were equipped with handholds and footholds to help those climbing in and out of themтАЩ. This explains the purpose of the handholds and footholds: it tells us what they were used for. 7 The correct answer is FALSE: In the third paragraph, the text describes the тАШcounterexcavation methodтАЩ and then says, тАШIt was used to cut through high mountains when the qanat method was not a practical alternative.тАЩ This means that the counter-excavation method did not completely replace the qanat method; it was used as an alternative in situations where it would have been too difficult to use the qanat method. 8 The correct answer is NOT GIVEN: Although the text does describe the tasks of the builders, it does not describe their levels of experience, nor does the text mention that only builders with experience were employed. 9 The correct answer is FALSE : In the third paragraph, the text says, тАШAn inscription written on the side of a 428-meter tunnel, built by the Romans as part of the Saldae aqueduct system in modern-day Algeria, describes how the two teams of builders missed each other in the mountain and how the later construction of a lateral link between both corridors corrected the initial error.тАЩ This means that the information about the problem was recorded on an inscription in the tunnel, not in a book. 10 The correct answer is TRUE : In the third paragraph, the text explains how a тАШtunnel was constructed from both endsтАЩ and how it тАШhad to meet correctly at the center of the mountainтАЩ. It then refers to the inscription in the Saldae aqueduct system tunnel which тАШdescribes how the two teams of builders missed each other in the mountain and how the later construction of a lateral link between both corridors corrected the initial errorтАЩ. In other words, the two parts of the tunnel failed to meet. 11 The correct answer is тАШgoldтАЩ: In the fourth paragraph, the text refers to Roman tunnels тАШbuilt for mineral extractionтАЩ and then says, тАШTraces of such tunnels used to mine gold can still be found at the Dolaucothi mines in Wales.тАЩ 12 The correct answer is тАШ(the) architect(тАЩs) (name)тАЩ: Towards the end of the fifth paragraph, the text says, тАШMost tunnels had inscriptions showing the names of patrons who ordered construction and sometimes the name of the architect.тАЩ If a name is on an inscription in a tunnel, this means that this personтАЩs name is carved on the tunnel. 13 The correct answer is тАШ(the) harbourтАЩ or тАШ(the) harborтАЩ: At the end of the fifth paragraph, the text says that the ├Зevlik tunnel was тАШbuilt to divert the floodwater threatening the harbor of the ancient city of Seleuceia PieriaтАЩ. The fact that the harbour was threatened by floodwater means that the tunnel which diverted this water was built to protect it. Reading Passage 2 Questions 14тАУ26 14 The correct answer is A : The writer describes a scene in which people of all ages are using digital devices and then makes the comment, тАШUnbeknown to most of us, an invisible, gamechanging transformation links everyone in this pictureтАЩ. The writer is making the point that this use of technology is causing тАШan invisible тАж transformationтАЩ, in other words, a hidden effect. The phrase тАШUnbeknown to most of usтАЩ means that most people are unaware of the transformation: this reinforces the idea that the effect is hidden. B is incorrect: The writer does not say anything about helping young people to read. C is incorrect: The writer does not give an opinion about whether using technology on planes should be encouraged. D is incorrect: The writer mentions different uses of technology but does not compare them. 15 The correct answer is B: The text refers to Sherry TurkleтАЩs view that тАШwe do not err as a society when we innovate but when we ignore what we disrupt or diminish while innovatingтАЩ. This tells us that Turkle believes it is a serious mistake not to consider the negative effects of innovation, including тАШwhat we тАж diminishтАЩ: in other words, what is lost. A is incorrect: The text does not say anything about a reduction in print reading. C is incorrect: The text does not refer to young people becoming involved in innovation. D is incorrect: The text does not mention any comparison between developing products and developing ideas. 16 The correct answer is D: The writer refers to the fact that the brainтАЩs reading circuit тАШneeds an environment to developтАЩ and says that тАШit will adapt to that environmentтАЩs requirements тАУ from different writing systems to the characteristics of whatever medium is usedтАЩ. This means that the circuit will adjust in any way that it is required. A is incorrect: The writer points out that, unlike vision and language, reading is not an inborn human ability. B is incorrect: The fact that there are different reading mediums is mentioned, but this is not the point which the writer is making in the paragraph. C is incorrect: The writer says that the brain is required to adapt to different writing systems but does not say that these demands are unexpected. 17 The correct answer is B: The text says that Mark Edmundson тАШdescribes how many college students actively avoid the classic literature of the 19th and 20th centuries in favour of something simpler as they no longer have the patience to read longer, denser, more difficult textsтАЩ. He is saying that studentsтАЩ impatience with more difficult texts (their attitude) means that they choose to read simple reading matter rather than classic 19th- and 20th-century literature. A is incorrect: Edmundson does not mention having changed the way he teaches. C is incorrect: Edmundson does not make a comparison between his own level of concern and that of other people. D is incorrect: Edmundson makes no reference to the views of the general public. 18 The correct answer is D : The writer says, тАШMultiple studies show that digital screen use may be causing a variety of troubling downstream effectsтАЩ. The word worrying has a similar meaning to тАШtroublingтАЩ. 19 The correct answer is H: The writer refers to Anne MangenтАЩs study and says, тАШResults indicated that students who read on print were superior in their comprehension to screenreading peers, particularly in their ability to sequence detailтАЩ. Having тАШsuperior тАж comprehensionтАЩ of the details of the plot has a similar meaning to having a more thorough understanding of it. 20 The correct answer is F: The writer refers to Anne MangenтАЩs study and says, тАШResults indicated that students who read on print were superior in their comprehension to screenreading peers, particularly in their ability to тАж reconstruct the plot in chronological order.тАЩ If the students who read on print were more able to reconstruct the plot in chronological order, this means that those who read screens found it hard (were less able) to recall the order of information in the story. 21 The correct answer is B : The writer refers to Ziming LiuтАЩs finding тАШthat the тАЬnew normтАЭ in reading is skimming, involving word-spotting and browsing through the textтАЩ. The phrase тАШthe new normтАЩ describes a current tendency. The term тАШword-spottingтАЩ describes the strategy of picking out single or isolated words and phrases located throughout the text. 22 The correct answer is C: The writer says, тАШWhen the reading brain skims like this, it reduces time allocated to deep reading processes. In other words, we donтАЩt have time to grasp complexity, to understand anotherтАЩs feelings, to perceive beauty, and to create thoughts of the readerтАЩs own.тАЩ Not having time to тАШgrasp complexityтАЩ and тАШunderstand anotherтАЩs feelingsтАЩ has a similar meaning to only gaining a superficial understanding of a textтАЩs emotional content. 23 The correct answer is YES: In the penultimate paragraph (the paragraph before the final one), the writer refers to тАШhow we all have begun to read on various mediums and how that changes not only what we read, but also the purposes for which we readтАЩ. In this sentence, the word тАШthatтАЩ refers back to the fact that we have all begun to read on various mediums. The writer is suggesting that we choose reading content according to the particular medium that we are using. 24 The correct answer is NO: In the penultimate paragraph, the writer refers to the loss of complex reading skills and says, тАШNor is it only about the young. The subtle atrophy of critical analysis and empathy affects us all equally.тАЩ 25 The correct answer is NOT GIVEN: In the penultimate paragraph, the writer says that our loss of complex reading skills is тАШleaving us susceptible to false informationтАЩ but does not say whether false information has become more widespread today. 26 The correct answer is YES: In the final paragraph, the writer says, тАШWe possess both the science and the technology to identify and redress the changes in how we read before they become entrenched.тАЩ When referring to problems, the word тАШredressтАЩ means to rectify, correct or put right. тАШBefore they become entrenchedтАЩ means before they become firmly established, meaning that we still have the chance or opportunity to rectify these problems. Reading Passage 3 Questions 27тАУ40 27 The correct answer is iii: The text gives examples of AI predictions and says, тАШAI is almost always better at forecasting than we areтАЩ. 28 The correct answer is vi: The text says that тАШif Watson generated a recommendation that contradicted the expertsтАЩ opinion, doctors would typically conclude that Watson wasnтАЩt competentтАЩ. The writer also uses the phrase тАШeven more suspicion and disbeliefтАЩ to refer to doctorsтАЩ reactions and says that many doctors chose to тАШignore the seemingly outlandish AI recommendations and stick to their own expertiseтАЩ. The word тАШsuspicionтАЩ and the fact that doctors chose to rely on their own expertise rather than AI recommendations indicate distrust. The phrases тАШeven more suspicionтАЩ and тАШmany doctorsтАЩ indicate that this distrust was widespread. 29 The correct answer is ii: The text gives three reasons why we have more faith in human judgement than in AI: our lack of familiarity with AI, our lack of understanding of how AI works and our perception that AI often goes wrong. First, it explains that тАШTrust in other people is often based on our understanding of how others think and having experience of their reliability. This helps create a psychological feeling of safetyтАЩ, and then contrasts this with our relative lack of familiarity with AI: тАШAI, on the other hand, is still fairly new and unfamiliar to most peopleтАЩ. Next, it says that тАШAIтАЩs decision-making process is usually too difficultтАЩ to understand and explains that тАШinteracting with something we donтАЩt understand can cause anxiety and give us a sense that weтАЩre losing controlтАЩ. Finally, the text mentions the fact that тАШEmbarrassing AI failures receive a disproportionate amount of media attention, emphasising the message that we cannot rely on technology.тАЩ 30 The correct answer is i: The text refers to an experiment focusing on positive and negative views of AI which found that тАШsimply watching a cinematic vision of our technological future polarised the participantsтАЩ attitudesтАЩ. If something тАШpolarises attitudesтАЩ, this means that it divides them into two opposing groups. The text then goes on to emphasise this increasing divergence of attitudes, saying, тАШOptimists became more extreme in their enthusiasm for AI and sceptics became even more guarded.тАЩ 31 The correct answer is vii: The text refers to ways of improving trust in AI and then it says тАШAnother solution may be to reveal more about the algorithms which AI uses and the purposes they serve. Several high-profile social media companies and online marketplaces already release transparency reports about government requests and surveillance disclosures.тАЩ The words тАШrevealтАЩ, тАШtransparency reportsтАЩ and тАШdisclosuresтАЩ are all connected with the idea of openness. The text then says, тАШA similar practice for AI could help people have a better understanding of the way algorithmic decisions are made.тАЩ In this sentence, the writer is suggesting that this kind of openness should be encouraged. 32 The correct answer is v: The text refers to some research and says, тАШone study showed that when people were allowed the freedom to slightly modify an algorithm, they felt more satisfied with its decisions, more likely to believe it was superior and more likely to use it in the futureтАЩ. Allowing people to тАШslightly modify an algorithmтАЩ is an example of involving users in AI processes, and the three positive results of this are examples of advantages. The text then says that тАШif people are given a degree of responsibility for how [AI systems] are implemented, they will be more willing to accept AI into their livesтАЩ. This is a further example of involving users in AI processes and a further advantage which results from the involvement. 33 The correct answer is C: The text gives examples of what AI can do and then highlights the existence of a problem, saying, тАШYet for all these technological advances, we still seem to deeply lack confidence in AI predictions.тАЩ A is incorrect: The writer expresses concern about our lack of confidence in AI but does not provide any solutions in this section. B is incorrect: The writer gives an opinion but does not justify it. D is incorrect: The writer describes a phenomenon but does not explain reasons for it. 34 The correct answer is B: The text says, тАШAIтАЩs decision-making process is usually too difficult for most people to comprehend. And interacting with something we donтАЩt understand can cause anxiety and give us a sense that weтАЩre losing control.тАЩ тАШAnxietyтАЩ and тАШa sense of losing controlтАЩ are examples of feeling at a disadvantage. A is incorrect: The text mentions AIтАЩs decisionmaking processes but does not say anything about AI replacing humans in decision-making jobs. C is incorrect: The text does not say anything about people wanting to wait for the technology to be tested. D is incorrect: The text does not say anything about AI seeming more challenging than it really is. 35 The correct answer is A: The text says, тАШEmbarrassing AI failures receive a disproportionate amount of media attention, emphasising the message that we cannot rely on technology.тАЩ If media gives people тАШthe message that we cannot rely on technologyтАЩ, it causes them to be mistrustful of it. B is incorrect: The text says that AI failures receive a disproportionate amount of media attention compared with AI successes; it does not say that the media devotes an excessive amount of attention to AI in general. C is incorrect: The text says that the amount of attention the media gives to AI failures is disproportionate; it does not say that media reports involving AI are inaccurate. D is incorrect: The text refers to AI failures but does not mention any causes of these failures. 36 The correct answer is NO: In Section D, the writer refers to an experiment involving subjective depictions of AI in sci-fi films where тАШOptimists became more extreme in their enthusiasm for AI and sceptics became even more guarded.тАЩ In other words, positive attitudes became even more positive and negative attitudes became even more negative. This indicates that the writer believes these depictions strengthen peopleтАЩs existing opinions about automation: they do not make people change their opinions. 37 The correct answer is NOT GIVEN: In Section D, the writer mentions the increasing representation of AI in the media but does not say whether media portrayals are likely to become more positive. 38 The correct answer is YES: In Section D, the writer says that тАШrefusing to accept the advantages offered by AI could place a large group of people at a serious disadvantageтАЩ. This means that it may have a negative effect on their lives. 39 The correct answer is NO: In Section E, the writer says, тАШSimply having previous experience with AI can significantly improve peopleтАЩs opinions about the technology, as was found in the study mentioned above. Evidence also suggests the more you use other technologies such as the internet, the more you trust them.тАЩ This indicates that the writer believes familiarity with AI can have a large impact on peopleтАЩs attitudes to technology. 40 The correct answer is YES: In Section F, the writer says that тАШone study showed that when people were allowed the freedom to slightly modify an algorithm, they felt more satisfied with its decisions, more likely to believe it was superior and more likely to use it in the futureтАЩ. This list of positive results corresponds to the idea of consumer approval. The writer therefore believes that AI applications which users are able to modify are more likely to gain consumer approval.
posts.excerpt_clean: Reading Passage 1 Questions 1тАУ13 1 The correct answer is тАШpostsтАЩ: In the first paragraph, the text describes the тАШqanat methodтАЩ of construction, тАШwhich consisted of placing posts over a hill in a straight line, to ensure that the tunnel kept to its routeтАЩ. posts.title: Cambridge Academic Reading 16 Test 3
posts.content_clean: Reading Passage 1 Questions 1тАУ13 1 The correct answer is FALSE : The text says, тАШThe Romans were not traditionally sailors but mostly land-based people, who learned to build ships from the people that they conquered, namely the Greeks and the Egyptians.тАЩ In other words, the Romans picked up their shipbuilding skills from the Greeks and the Egyptians: they did not pass these skills on to these people. 2 The correct answer is NOT GIVEN : The text mentions the change to the тАШmortise and tenonтАЩ method of fixing planks but does not say whether skilled craftsmen were needed for this. 3 The correct answer is FALSE : The text says, тАШMediterranean shipbuilders shifted to another shipbuilding method, still in use today, which consisted of building the frame first and then proceeding with the hull and the other components of the ship.тАЩ In other words, their practice involved building the frame before the hull. 4 The correct answer is TRUE : The text says, тАШRomeтАЩs navy became the largest and most powerful in the Mediterranean, and the Romans had control over what they therefore called Mare Nostrum, meaning тАЬour seaтАЭтАЩ. This means that Romans gave the Mediterranean this name because they dominated its use. 5 The correct answer is TRUE : The text says that rowers were тАШmostly Roman citizens enrolled in the militaryтАЩ. 6 The correct answer is тАШlightweightтАЩ: In the third paragraph, the text says, тАШWarships were built to be lightweight and very speedyтАЩ. тАШSpeedyтАЩ is incorrect: The summary already says that warships were designed so that they moved quickly; тАШspeedyтАЩ has the same meaning as this. 7 The correct answer is тАШbronzeтАЩ: In the third paragraph, the text says, тАШThey had a bronze battering ramтАЩ. тАШTimberтАЩ is incorrect: This refers to the hulls of enemy ships. 8 The correct answer is тАШlevelsтАЩ : In the fourth paragraph, the text refers to the тАШtriremeтАЩ and then says, тАШIt had rowers in the top, middle and lower levelsтАЩ. 9 The correct answer is тАШhullтАЩ: In the fifth paragraph, the text says that merchant ships тАШhad a wider hull, double planking and a solid interior for added stabilityтАЩ. The word broad has the same meaning as тАШwideтАЩ. тАШInteriorтАЩ is incorrect: the text says that the interior was тАШsolidтАЩ, not that it was wide. 10 The correct answer is тАШtriangularтАЩ: In the fifth paragraph, the text says that merchant ships had тАШone to three masts with large square sails and a small triangular sail at the bowтАЩ. тАШLargeтАЩ is incorrect: the gap requires a word describing the shape of the sails, contrasting with тАШsquareтАЩ and referring to the other type of sail (тАШsmall triangularтАЩ). 11 The correct answer is тАШmusicтАЩ: In the fifth paragraph, the text says that тАШcoordinating the hundreds of rowers тАж was not an easy taskтАЩ and then says, тАШIn order to assist them, music would be played on an instrument, and oars would keep time with this.тАЩ 12 The correct answer is тАШgrainтАЩ: In the sixth paragraph, the text says, тАШThe cargo on merchant ships included raw materials, (e.g. iron bars, copper, marble and granite), and agricultural products, (e.g. grain from EgyptтАЩs Nile valley).тАЩ 13 The correct answer is тАШtowboatsтАЩ: In the sixth paragraph, the text says, тАШLarge merchant ships would approach the destination port and, just like today, be intercepted by a number of towboats that would drag them to the quay.тАЩ The phrase тАШdrag them to the quayтАЩ means that these small boats pulled the merchant ships to the shore. Reading Passage 2 Questions 14тАУ26 14 The correct answer is D: The text says, тАШHunters would have easily misplaced arrows and they often discarded broken bows rather than take them all the way home.тАЩ This sentence gives two reasons why hunters left weapons in the mountains: it explains about arrows that were тАШmisplacedтАЩ тАУ in other words, lost тАУ and bows that hunters threw away because they were broken. A is incorrect: Section A refers to ancient arrows being found on mountains, but it does not explain why they were left there. 15 The correct answer is C: The text quotes Barrett saying, тАШFieldwork is hard work тАУ hiking with all our equipment, often camping on permafrostтАЩ. The term тАШfieldworkтАЩ refers to the work of archaeologists when they go to excavate ancient sites looking for evidence. F is incorrect: Section F mentions the difficulty of travelling in the mountains, but this refers to travel in the ancient past: it does not refer to present-day archaeological expeditions. 16 The correct answer is F: The text quotes Barrett referring to тАШfailing agricultural harvests in time of low temperaturesтАЩ and then says, тАШA colder turn in the Scandinavian climate would likely have meant widespread crop failuresтАЩ. These are both explanations about the climate becoming too cold to grow food successfully. 17 The correct answer is H: The text says that тАШarchaeologists could be extracting some of those artefacts from retreating ice in years to comeтАЩ. The phrase тАШin years to comeтАЩ means in the future. 18 The correct answer is G: The text refers to тАШa booming demand for hides to fight off the cold, as well as antlers to make useful things like combs.тАЩ Hides (animal skins) and antlers are examples of two animal products which people needed and which hunters would have traded. C and E are not correct: Sections C and E mention trade but do not give any examples of items. 19 The correct answer is B: The text says, тАШglacial archaeologists need to race the clock to find newly revealed artefacts, preserve them, and study themтАЩ. The idiom тАШrace against the clockтАЩ refers to the pressure to do something quickly before time runs out. The text then gives two examples explaining why they have to work quickly: тАШIf something fragile dries and is windblown it might very soon be lost to science, or an arrow might be exposed and then covered again by the next snowтАЩ. C is incorrect: Section C refers to how hard archaeologistsтАЩ work can be, but makes no mention of the pressure to work quickly. 20 The correct answer is тАШmicroorganismsтАЩ or тАШmicro-organismsтАЩ: In Section B, the text says, тАШOrganic materials like textiles and hides are relatively rare finds at archaeological sites. This is because unless theyтАЩre protected from the microorganisms that cause decay, they tend not to last long.тАЩ The term тАШhidesтАЩ is another word for animal skins. 21 The correct answer is тАШreindeerтАЩ: In Section C, the text refers to тАШpatches of ice in OpplandтАЩ and then says, тАШReindeer once congregated on these icy patches in the later summer monthsтАЩ. The word тАШcongregatedтАЩ means came together in groups, so has a similar meaning to gathered. тАШInsectsтАЩ is incorrect: The text does not say that the insects were trying to avoid anything. тАШHuntersтАЩ is incorrect: The text does not say that hunters gathered or that they were trying to avoid anything. 22 The correct answer is тАШinsectsтАЩ: In Section C, the text refers to reindeer congregating on the mountains of Oppland in summer тАШto escape biting insectsтАЩ. This means that they went up to the mountains to avoid being attacked by the insects. тАШReindeerтАЩ is incorrect: The text says that the reindeer were trying to avoid the insects, not that the insects were trying to avoid the reindeer. тАШHuntersтАЩ is incorrect: The text does not say that the reindeer were trying to avoid hunters. 23 and 24 The correct answers are B and C: In Section F, the text says, тАШBut it turned out that hunters kept regularly venturing into the mountains even when the climate turned coldтАЩ: this has the same meaning as statement B. In Section E, the text refers to some periods which produced lots of artefacts, indicating that people were active at those times and then says, тАШBut there were few or no signs of activity during other periodsтАЩ: this means that there were few or no artefacts in these other periods. A is incorrect: In Section D, the text mentions tools and horse tack (horse equipment) as examples of artefacts other than skis which were found in high mountain passes. D is incorrect: Radiocarbon dating is mentioned in Section E, but the text does not say anything about results being inaccurate. E is incorrect: The text does not compare the number of artefacts found in Oppland with those found in other sites. 25 and 26 The correct answers are A and C : In Section G, the text refers to тАШa booming demand for hides to fight off the cold, as well as antlers to make useful things like combs. Business must have been good for hunters.тАЩ The phrase тАШa booming demandтАЩ has the same meaning as an increased demand. This section also says, тАШAlthough we usually think of ships when we think of Scandinavian expansion, these recent discoveries show that plenty of goods travelled on overland routes, like the mountain passes of Oppland.тАЩ This means that not all Viking goods were transported by ship: some were transported by land. B is incorrect: The text does not say when the greatest growth in the wealth of the Vikings occurred. D is incorrect: The text does not say where traders of this time came from. E is incorrect: The text does not say which area the Vikings were interested in with regard to trading links. Reading Passage 3 Questions 27тАУ40 27 The correct answer is NOT GIVEN: In Section A, the text refers to the Cambridge scientistsтАЩ discovery and the publication of their findings, but does not mention other scientistsтАЩ reaction to this. 28 The correct answer is TRUE: In Section D, Dr Philip Wigge refers to the target for 2050 and then says, тАШbut climate change is a major threat to achieving this.тАЩ If there is a major threat to achieving something, this means that it might not be achieved. 29 The correct answer is TRUE: In Section D, the text says, тАШKey crops such as wheat and rice are sensitive to high temperatures. Thermal stress reduces crop yields by around 10% for every one degree increase in temperatureтАЩ. If crop yields are reduced, this means that the crops suffer when temperatures increase. 30 The correct answer is NOT GIVEN: There is no mention of the possibility of developing crops that require less water. 31 The correct answer is FALSE: In Section E, the text says, тАШDuring the day, sunlight activates the molecules, slowing down growth. If a plant finds itself in shade, phytochromes are quickly inactivated тАУ enabling it to grow faster to find sunlight again.тАЩ This means that plants grow more slowly in sunlight than in shade. 32 The correct answer is FALSE: In Section E, the text says, тАШAt night, however, itтАЩs a different story. Instead of a rapid deactivation following sundown, the molecules gradually change from their active to inactive state.тАЩ This means that phytochromes change their state at different speeds day and night: in the daytime, they become active or deactivated quickly, depending on light levels; by night, they change slowly, depending on temperature. 33 The correct answer is H : The text quotes Wigge saying, тАШwe have outstanding collaborators nearby who work on more applied aspects of plant biology, and can help us transfer this new knowledge into the fieldтАЩ. This means that the collaboratorsтАЩ specialised knowledge of plant biology can help the researchers take their findings out of the lab, so that they can be used in тАШthe fieldтАЩ тАУ a wider, real-world context. 34 The correct answer is D: The text quotes Wigge saying, тАШтАШDiscovering the molecules that allow plants to sense temperature has the potential to accelerate the breeding of crops resilient to thermal stress and climate change.тАЩ If the researchersтАЩ discovery can speed up the development of crops that donтАЩt suffer in rising temperatures, this would be a potential benefit. 35 The correct answer is G: The text quotes the well-known rhyme, тАШoak before ash weтАЩll have a splash, ash before oak weтАЩre in for a soakтАЩ, followed by WiggeтАЩs explanation about why this traditional saying has a scientific basis. 36 The correct answer is C: The text says, тАШFarmers and gardeners have known for hundreds of years how responsive plants are to temperature: warm winters cause many trees and flowers to bud early, something humans have long used to predict weather and harvest times for the coming year.тАЩ This sentence mentions trees and flowers budding early as an example of plant behaviour, and says that people have long used this as an indication of future conditions: for example, in helping farmers to plan when their crops will need to be harvested. If something has been known for hundreds of years or if people have тАШlongтАЩ done something, this means that it has been done тАШtraditionallyтАЩ. 37 The correct answer is A: The text refers to тАШThe new findings, published in the journal ScienceтАЩ. If researchers publish their findings in a journal, this where their research is reported. 38 The correct answer is тАШwarm (winter)тАЩ: In Section G, the text says that тАШspecies, such as daffodils, have considerable temperature sensitivity, and can flower months in advance during a warm winterтАЩ. 39 The correct answer is тАШsummerтАЩ: In Section G, the text says, тАШA warmer spring, and consequently a higher likeliness of a hot summer, will result in oak leafing before ash. A cold spring will see the opposite. As the British know only too well, a colder summer is likely to be a rain-soaked one.тАЩ The phrase тАШa cold spring will see the oppositeтАЩ means that a cold spring will result in ash trees coming into leaf before oak trees, and that there will also be a higher chance of a cold and тАШrain-soakedтАЩ (wet) summer. 40 The correct answer is тАШmustard plant(s)тАЩ or тАШmustardтАЩ: In Section H, the text says, тАШThe work was done in a model system, using a mustard plant called Arabidopsis.
